title: What does the abbreviation 'DOM' stand for in JavaScript?
answer_1: Document Object Model
answer_2: Data Object Model
answer_3: Dynamic Object Model
right_answer: Document Object Model

title: What does the 'typeof' operator in JavaScript do?
answer_3: It returns the type of a variable or expression
answer_2: It converts a value to a specified type
answer_1: It checks if a variable or expression is null
right_answer: It returns the type of a variable or expression

title: What does the 'NaN' stand for in JavaScript?
answer_1: Not a Null
answer_2: Not a Number
answer_3: Null and None
right_answer: Not a Number

title: Which keyword is used to declare a variable in JavaScript?
answer_2: let
answer_3: const
answer_1: variable
right_answer: var

title: What is the correct way to write a JavaScript array?
answer_1: var colors = ["Red", "Green", "Blue"]
answer_2: colors = "Red", "Green", "Blue"
answer_3: colors = {"Red", "Green", "Blue"}
right_answer: var colors = ["Red", "Green", "Blue"]

title: What is the purpose of the 'setTimeout' function in JavaScript?
answer_1: To call a function after a specified delay
answer_2: To set the time on the device's clock
answer_3: To stop the execution of a function
answer_4: To repeat the execution of a function at regular intervals
right_answer: To call a function after a specified delay

title: What does the '==='' operator in JavaScript do?
answer_1: Checks if two values are equal in value and type
answer_2: Converts a value to a boolean
answer_3: Checks if two values are equal in value only
answer_4: Checks if two values are not equal
right_answer: Checks if two values are equal in value and type

title: What is the purpose of the 'typeof' operator in JavaScript?
answer_1: To determine the type of a variable or expression
answer_2: To perform arithmetic operations
answer_3: To convert a value to a string
right_answer: To determine the type of a variable or expression

title: What is the correct way to write a JavaScript comment for a single line?
answer_1: // This is a comment
answer_2: <!-- This is a comment -->
answer_3: /* This is a comment */
right_answer: // This is a comment

title: What does the 'typeof null' return in JavaScript?
answer_1: null
answer_2: object
answer_3: undefined
right_answer: object

title: What is the purpose of the 'console.log()' function in JavaScript?
answer_1: To log messages to the console for debugging purposes
answer_2: To create a new console window in the browser
answer_3: To log messages to the server
answer_4: To display messages in an alert box
right_answer: To log messages to the console for debugging purposes

title: What does the 'let' keyword do in JavaScript?
answer_1: Declares a variable with block scope
answer_2: Declares a variable with function scope
answer_3: Declares a constant variable
right_answer: Declares a variable with block scope

title: What is the purpose of the 'addEventListener()' method in JavaScript?
answer_1: To remove an event listener from an element
answer_2: To add an event listener to an element
answer_3: To trigger an event on an element
answer_4: To handle errors in JavaScript code
right_answer: To add an event listener to an element

title: What does the 'this' keyword refer to in JavaScript?
answer_1: Refers to the current function
answer_2: Refers to the global object
answer_3: Refers to the object that is executing the current function
right_answer: Refers to the object that is executing the current function

title: What is the purpose of the 'JSON.stringify()' method in JavaScript?
answer_1: Converts a JavaScript object to a JSON string
answer_2: Converts a JSON string to a JavaScript object
answer_3: Parses a JSON string
right_answer: Converts a JavaScript object to a JSON string

title: What does the 'querySelector()' method do in JavaScript?
answer_1: Selects the first element that matches a specified CSS selector
answer_2: Selects all elements that match a specified CSS selector
answer_3: Selects the parent element of a specified element
answer_4: Selects the child elements of a specified element
right_answer: Selects the first element that matches a specified CSS selector

title: What is the purpose of the 'parseInt()' function in JavaScript?
answer_1: Converts a string to a floating-point number
answer_2: Converts a string to an integer
answer_3: Converts a string to a boolean value
answer_4: Converts a string to a date object
right_answer: Converts a string to an integer

title: What does the 'Array.isArray()' method do in JavaScript?
answer_1: Checks if a variable is an array
answer_2: Converts an array to a string
answer_3: Adds an element to the end of an array
answer_4: Removes the first element from an array
right_answer: Checks if a variable is an array

title: What is the purpose of the 'Math.random()' method in JavaScript?
answer_1: Generates a random number between 0 and 1
answer_2: Generates a random integer between two specified values
answer_3: Rounds a number to the nearest integer
answer_4: Returns the square root of a number
right_answer: Generates a random number between 0 and 1

title: What does the 'slice()' method do on arrays in JavaScript?
answer_1: Returns a portion of the array
answer_2: Removes the last element of the array
answer_3: Adds elements to the beginning of the array
answer_4: Sorts the elements of the array
right_answer: Returns a portion of the array
